Holy Grale raises the bar with impressive menu

There's more than craft beer on tap at restaurant in a former church

Holy Grale raises the bar with impressive menu

Nancy Miller, Special to The Courier-Journal 4:06 p.m. EDT October 28, 2014
The 3D Valley Farm Burger at Holy Grale is made with Benton's bacon, caramelized onions, cheddar, arugula, and fritje sauce. (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Red Curry Mussels at Holy Grale are prepared with coconut milk, cilantro, and lime and served with grilled bread. (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The menu at Holy Grale describes the Fritjes Poutine as: "Kenny's cheese curds, bread & butter pickles, chicken gravy." (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Built in 1905 as a Unitarian Church in the Original Highlands, 1034 Bardstown Road is now occupied by Holy Grale. With 26 taps and original architectural details in tact, their website states "Good beer and good company is the only thing we pray for in this house of worship." (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Built in 1905 as a Unitarian Church in the Original Highlands, 1034 Bardstown Road is now occupied by Holy Grale. With 26 taps and original architectural details in tact, their website states "Good beer and good company is the only thing we pray for in this house of worship." (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Dry-Rubbed Pork Steak at Holy Grale is served with weisenberger grits, carrot-pear butter, roasted turnips, Brussels sprouts, and sorghum gastrique. (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Built in 1905 as a Unitarian Church in the Original Highlands, 1034 Bardstown Road is now occupied by Holy Grale.     Built in 1905 as a Unitarian Church in the Original Highlands, the building at 1034 Bardstown Road is now occupied by Holy Grale. With 26 taps and original architectural details intact, the craft beer bars website states: Good beer and good company is the only thing we pray for in this house of worship. (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The Courier-Journal )

    Story Highlights

    • 3 1/2 stars out of 4
    • Address: 1034 Bardstown Road Telephone: (502) 459-9939 Web:holygralelouisville.com
    • Cuisine: New American. Alcohol: Beer only. Vegetarian: Yes. Price range: Inexpensive to moderate.
    • Children's menu: No. Must be at least 21 to enter. Smoking: No. Access: The first floor bar/dining room appears to be fully accessible for people using wheelchairs without assistance. Hours: Monday-Thursday, 4-11 p.m.; Friday, 4 p.m.-midnight; Saturday, 1 p.m.-midnight; Sunday, 1-11 p.m.
    16 CONNECT 10 TWEET 1 LINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

    If you're exhausted after a long day, which I was, and if you're in a bad mood, which I was, and if you desperately need to buoy up your mood, which I did, get yourself to Holy Grale, which I did.

    Holy Grale is a craft beer bar housed in a century-old former church, where ecclesiastical vestiges remain, not at all somberly, but very hospitably. Before you say, "Oh, it's only a bar," let me tell you, there are bars and there's Holy Grale. It's a bar with an impressive and extensive list of beers and a chef with a very plucky menu.

    The first floor bar/dining room is comfortably snug and dimly lit. Since there are 26 beers on tap and more than 60 different bottled beers, it's only fitting that the back bar, triptych and all, is a showy display of an assortment of beer glasses. There's a glass for every style of beer. A church pew, the barrel staves bar, brick wall and beamed ceiling aren't there only for effect. They're reclaimed and repurposed for authentically appropriate design.

    Holy Grale attracts a seriously devoted and knowledgeable beer crowd, but they're not a cliquish group that looks askance on those with a low beer IQ. The staff will cordially discuss with you the beers' flavor profiles and will suggest beers that match your preferences, such as sweet or sour, dry or crisp, hoppy or bitter. There's not a chance of beer boredom here, as every day a couple of beers are switched out.

    I have never met chef Joshua Lehman, but his menu strikes me as having been created by someone who isn't about to let the beers outclass the food. Some of his dishes sneak up on you with unfolding tiers of flavors, and others are bold and bodacious from the first bite.

    Red curry mussels ($9) were piled high in a smooth coconut broth that was nicely intensified with cilantro and lime. Concerns about etiquette may preclude you from guzzling the broth straight from the bowl, even if no one is watching. If so, don't be shy about asking for an extra piece of toasted bread that you can use to soak up every drop of broth.

    Lehman piles high again with the 3D Valley Farm burger ($14). A trio of bacon, caramelized onions and cheddar cheese are layered on the beef inside a pretzel bun. It would be almost impossible to go wrong with layers like that, but the chef goes a step beyond and adds fritje sauce, a mayonnaise-y, mustard-y concoction. It indicates he believes that merely good is not nearly good enough.

    MORE REVIEWS: Majid's small plates big on flavor

    MORE REVIEWS: Blackstone Grille gets it right

    Your cardiologist would likely cover your mouth with duct tape at the mere suggestion of the poutine ($12), double fried potatoes topped with chicken gravy and cheese curds. That's why you need to keep the poutine a secret from your doc and from your fatty foods-forbidding friends.

    Was Lehman's pairing the hot fried quail ($14) with grits, pickles, sweet corn and green onion kimchi a haphazard, attention-getting move? It got our attention, but I don't think anything he does is haphazard. My son Alex asked, "How's the quail?" I answered that he needed to taste it for himself. That's a mother's love for you, sharing with your child even while hoping he would decline the offer. He confirmed what I knew to be true. Quail is a little bird, but this is a big-tasting dish.

    Pork loin with sorghum gastrique ($16) was unpretentious, unfussy and over the top of the flavor scale. I talked about it the next day to anyone who would listen and to a couple of people who wouldn't. Lucky for the former and too bad for the latter.

    Our dinner was only an inkling of the New American menu that includes a charcuterie plate ($15) with ham, chicken liver mousse and porkstrami; a rotating choice of pate ($10); shiitake sliders ($12); pan-seared cauliflower ($8); and escargot ($8). The menu changes when Lehman feels like changing it.

    Service at Holy Grail is friendly though limited. If you have dinner on the first floor, you'll need to place your order at the bar. There is table service only in the upstairs Choir Loft.

    Leave the kids at home. No one under 21 is allowed to partake.

    You can email freelance restaurant critic Nancy Miller at millermadison@aol.com. Follow @WhatNancyThinks on Twitter.
